content.text:
Keyboard:
Menu:
Move - W or S
Select - K

In Game: 
Move - A or D
Jump - J
Attack - K
Dash - O

Gamepad:
Menu:
Move - D-Pad
Select - Cross or A

In Game:
Move: D-Pad or Left Stick
Jump: Cross or A
Attack: Square or X
Dash: Circle or B

events.comment:
This project is meant as a game example or template for a more advanced platformer. This is in the style of older castlevania entries, such as Castlevania 1 or 3.
There are numerous advanced GDevelop concepts in this project, such as finite state machines (FSMs), tweens, bitmap fonts and bitmap text objects, tilemaps, external event sheets, declaring variables via events, and object variables. 

Before working with this project, it is STRONGLY recommended that you review the following:
At least the first four tutorials on the GDevelop Wiki: http://wiki.compilgames.net/doku.php/gdevelop5/tutorials. This example uses concepts from EACH of those tutorials and it is important to understand those concepts before trying to adapt these ideas.
The finite state machine tutorial at: http://wiki.compilgames.net/doku.php/gdevelop5/tutorials/finite_state_machine

The following events help with some of the aesthetics of the title screen by centering the title screen and menu item text on the X axis.
The Menu Border object is then centered based off the middle menu item.
Finally, the Menu Selector object is centered and placed over the Start Game object.
We also use this event to play the title music.
The fade object is hidden at the start of the scene, then stretched to the width/height of the screen and positioned so it covers the entire screen.
Whenever starting or returning to the title screen, set the Checkpoint and Lives global variables to their default.

The game engine by default sends anonymous statistics to the project. This is helpful for developers on games as well as the developers behind GDevelop.
If desired, this can easily be disabled with the below event, although this example leaves it enabled.

To ensure that menu selector only moves once when a movement key is pressed, a variable is used to restrict the ability to move at all after moving once. 
This variable needs to be switched back once all movement buttons are not pressed, and this is accomplished by checking that it is currently restricted, then checking that no buttons are pressed, then switching it back.
The events shouldn't occur unless the selector has been released since last press AND the fade out hasn't started.

Move the Selector Up or Down based off the gamepad button or keyboard key pressed.
To select the correct menu item to move to, the Up or Down variables are compared to the MenuTextItem group to find the matching Item.
The selector is then moved to the Y position of the correct MenuTextItem, -16 pixels to center the selector.
Once the selector is not moving, and the movement buttons are released, the scene variables tracking the current ID and possible movement IDs are updated.

As the screen should fade out once an object is selected, these events check that the movement has been completed, then starts the opacity tween of the Fade Object.
Also play the select sound once.

Once the fade out has finished, collision is tested between the selector and Menu Text Item, to find out which action is currently selected.
The action listed is then used to decide which scene to change to.

The main game includes many different object types and elements:
Sprite objects for the majority of player and enemy objects. 
Tiled sprite objects for the backgrounds.
Panel sprites (9-patch) objects for parts of the UI
Bitmap text objects fro any text.
A tilemap object for the world layout itself.

The tilemap was made in LDtk and then imported into Tiled Map Editor, then finally exported into JSON format for use with GDevelop. More about using Tiled Map Editor directly can be found here: http://wiki.compilgames.net/doku.php/gdevelop5/objects/tilemap#creating_a_new_tilemap_step_by_step
Collisions for the world are handled outside of the tileset, but making a single "platform" sprite object then placing as many as needed on the map, then stretching/rotating as required.

All enemy objects have object variables of enemyDMG and enemyHP for use with combat/damage management in later events.
The player has numerous object variables, those are explained in the various events that use them.
The main event sheet for the level only contains events that must be included at the start of the scene.
If the checkpoint has been reached, start the player at the checkpoint position.

Fade Object management
This is to stretch the FadeObject to the full screen size and then center it into the middle of the GUI camera.
Since this object is just a black square, resizing it via events lets it keep a much smaller asset size and not have to worry about memory limits.
This object is used whenever there is a need to fade out or in the screen, like for a GameOver or starting the level.

The main camera uses a large Camera "room" object, and some logic to follow the player in that room. Because the camera could be used in numerous levels, it is stored in an external event sheet.
More details are found in the event sheet.

The below event links the Finite State Machine (FSM) for our hero's movement.
All hero controls are done in these events, and not in the main event sheet, for many reasons:
1. Incase we make more levels in the future, this avoids having to remake or copy the events.
2. A finite state machine will help avoid major conflicts with competing controls.

Additionally, controls themselves are set up for both keyboard and gamepad. To allow for easier updating of controls, both the gamepad and keyboard conditions utilize global variables for their current settings.

There are 3 different type of normal enemies included, that adhere to many of the standard enemy AI tropes found in games.
The wolf enemy is a Dasher, which is an enemy that will start running in the direction it is facing once the player is within range of it.
The skeleton enemy is a Patroller, which is an enemy that walks back and forth on a predetermined path, and turns around after colliding with a wall or platform edge.
The ghost is a delayed chase enemy, which is an enemy that directly chases the player while they are in range, with a small delay between each movement.

Most Bosses are scene specific, and there is usually only one. With this in mind, the boss fight events are kept in the scene event sheet instead of as an external event.
The boss for the level has a very simple pattern, and only damages the player on contact.
The main goal is for the player to realize the boss is too large to jump over, and that dashing through the boss is required to survive.
The boss's possible locations are tracked via BossLocation objects. A single object is used for this with a "Location" instance variable. This allows for modification of the boss pattern without having to worry about manually tracking specific x/y locations.
Only start the boss fight logic if the BossFightStart variable is set to 1.
The BossPhase variable is used to act as a small state machine, to ensure the boss is only doing the desired events during that phase.
After the fight starts, the boss should wait a moment before the initial move.

After the initial timer has passed, the boss moves to the 3rd position with a tween.
By checking for the Location variable of the BossLocation object, the tween targets that specific object.

When the tween has finished, change the phase variable and restart the timer.
This should also end the cutscene for the player.
Since the boss should move to BossLocation 2 or 3 in numerous phases, an OR condition is used to remove the need to duplicate events numerous times.

To make sure the boss is always facing away from the wall, it is flipped horizontally after the move ends.
The phase is then increased by 1 to move onto the next phase.
Boss phases 4 and 8 has the boss move to the upper corners of the boss room, so they are separate from the 2 main phases.
Once the boss passes phase 10, there are no new movements, so reset to phase 1.

At the start of the scene, the fade object needs to fade to 0 opacity to create a "Fade In" effect.
This should be treated as a cutscene when fading in to prevent player/enemy movement.
Once the fade in is finished, end the cutscene.

Once the Boss Cutscene starts:
The camera starts following the hidden CutsceneCamera object.

The global cutscene state is started via a variable, to ensure the player can't move around while the cutscene is occurring.
A global checkpoint variable is also activated, to ensure that the player starts before the boss room if they die.
As the Cutscene variable disables player controls, the player needs to be moved right until it is past the barrier object.

As the player could be dashing or stop moving, check the current animation and force it to Run while the cutscene movement is happening.
To prevent any graphical oddities with the dash effect, also force the hero object to be on the base layer.
After the cutscene movement is done, move the Hero object back to the idle animation, and flag that the boss hero movement is done as a variable.

After the boss cutscene has started, the CutsceneCamera object's position is tweened to our desired location.
SInce the game camera now follows this object, it is also moved into the desired location.
After the movement is finished, flag that the Boss Camera Movement is done via a variable.
Only start moving the barriers after both the Hero and the Camera are done moving.

While the barriers are moving, fade out the stage music.
This is done using a clamp parameter to make sure it stops at 0 and doesn't cause any issues by going to a negative number.

After the barriers have finished moving, start the boss fight music.
Also set the variable to start the boss logic.
These events allow you to test and view the debug objects while previewing in the engine itself.

content.text:
Huge thanks to 4ian, Bouh, Arthuro555, and all of the GDevelop 
community over the years.

- GUI Assets -
HUD:  Adwitr on Itch.io / Mounir Tohami 
Title Font: Sanguis - Jupiter Hadley
GUI Font: Dogica Pixel - rmocci

- World Art Assets -
Map Tileset: Ansimuz
Player Character: Ansimuz
Monsters: Ansimuz

- Sound Assets -
Music: Jonathan So
Sword Sound Effect: Iwan Gabovich
Other Sounds: Created in GDevelop using JFXR

- Game Design and Development - 
Silver-Streak


Press the M key on the keyboard, the Y button on an Xbox Gamepad, or the Triangle on a Playstation Gamepad to return to the main menu.

events.comment: Center the credits text.
Events to return to the title screen.

content.text: You beat the example game in:

Next steps are to download and edit the project in GDevelop to learn more about making your own game. 

Feel free to check out GDevelop at http://gdevelop-app.com.

Press the M key on the keyboard, the Y button on an Xbox Gamepad, or the Triangle on a Playstation Gamepad to return to the main menu.

events.comment: By having all of the text objects in a group, only one event is needed to center all of them.
Resize and position the fade object, then start the fade in.
Once the fade is completed, play the victory music.

This external event sheet is the primary Finite State Machine (FSM) for the hero character.
This functions using an object variable on the Hero object, named heroFSM.
The main goal is to ensure that only the actions that *should* occur, *can* occur. 
Example: 
-The player has jump, attack, and dash buttons available to them. If the player is dashing, they should not be able to attack mid-dash. 
--Without a FSM, the attack events would then have to have extra conditions added to ensure it won't work while dashing. Then the same would need to be done for jump. As the hero also can't run while dashing, more conditions would need to be adde to the run events to avoid that there too. Every potential conflict will add more and more bloat to the events, and lead to potential logic or animation conflicts. 
--With a FSM, when the hero switches to the Dash State, the events simply do not set up any controls for jump, run, or attack, and they are ignored during the dash.

Learn more about FSMs here: 
http://wiki.compilgames.net/doku.php/gdevelop5/tutorials/finite_state_machine
https://gamedevelopment.tutsplus.com/tutorials/finite-state-machines-theory-and-implementation--gamedev-11867
The initialization state occurs at the beginning of the scene just to ensure there's no oddness when the scene begins.
If the game is in Cutscene mode, the hero shouldn't be able to use its normal states.
If the game is NOT in cutscene mode, the hero should switch to whatever state the heroFSM variable is set to.

The variable is set to InitState just for tracking purposes.
This sway if the heroFSM variable is ever set to InitState outside of the start of the scene, it indicates something has gone wrong.

These events are used to ensure that the player cannot hold a jump, dash, or attack button, and have the action spam whenever the hero switches states.
The variables listed must be 0 in order for the player to use the action again, so by not setting them back until the button is released we avoid spamming.
Movement actions are in this state so the hero can change direction while falling, without switching to the run animation.
These events are used to monitor and reset the hit state. This ensures the player has a short period of invulnerability before they can be damaged again.

Transition to the hit state if:
The player is not currently invulnerable (Opacity < 255).
The player collides with a member of the DamageToHero group.

Also subtract the damage of the enemy from the current hitpoints of the hero.
A clamp statement is used to ensure that the hero's HP never reduces below 0.
If the player fell into a pit, immediately move to the death state.
If the player did not fall into a pit, follow normal damage rules.
To avoid spamming any of the jumps, dashes, or attacks, require the player to release the key or button before they can be used again.

The following event resets a timer while the player is on a platform and running.
This allows for adding a "Coyote Time" style jump, which can be seen down in the transitions sections of this state.
This event is ONLY in the running state, to ensure it doesn't impact situations where a player is knocked back into mid-air, or on a crumbling platform.
To ensure that it doesn't get reset when the player is up against a wall and falling, it checks that the player is not jumping nor falling.
After being hit, allow for a moment of invulnerability, to avoid endlessly looping damage.

These movement events are set up to avoid potential conflicts from a player holding both left and right on the keyboard at the same time.
This is much less likely to happen if the game was set up for gamepad controls only, but CAN still occur.
To avoid this conflict, whatever direction is pressed first updates a Direction variable. Additional keypresses at the same time does not update this variable.
Once the original key is released, the other held direction takes priority.

Transition to the hit state if:
The player is not currently invulnerable (Opacity < 255).
The player collides with a member of the DamageToHero group.

Player can only dash if:
The dash button has been released since the last dash.
The current stamina is greater or equal to the dash cost.
The dash button or key is pressed.

Player can only jump normally if:
The jump button has been released since the last dash.
The player is on the floor.
The jump button or key is pressed.

The player can also jump if they have just recently started falling.
This is called Coyote Time, and helps with "Game feel".
This checks that a the CoyoteTime timer is less than a predefined time value. In the events below we're comparing against a Global Variable, so it's easier to change that time later on if needed. 
The value is set to 0.0833, which is roughly 5 frames.
The only difference between this and a normal jump is that we are forcing the jump to occur. This is because the game engine knows the player is falling and shouldn't be allowed to jump.
By allowing the player to jump again, and then forcing the jump, this makes it feel like a normal jump has occurred.
At the start of the state, switch the animation
To avoid spamming any of the jumps, dashes, or attacks, require the player to release the key or button before they can be used again.
After being hit, allow for a moment of invulnerability, to avoid endlessly looping damage.

Transition to the hit state if:
The player is not currently invulnerable (Opacity < 255).
The player collides with a member of the DamageToHero group. 
The player sprite (Hero) is used to collision detection, NOT the hitbox object, so that we can have more granular control over damage collision boxes without impacting the movement hitbox of the character.

Transition to the fall state if:
The player is falling.
These states can only be activated if the hero character is on the floor. This is to avoid conflicts between ground events and falling events.

Switch to Attack state if:
The player is on the floor (parent event)
The attack button has been released since last attack.
The attack button or key is pressed.

Switch to the Run state if: 
The player is on the floor (parent event)
One of the run buttons or keys are pressed.

Player can only dash if:
The dash button has been released since the last dash.
The current stamina is greater or equal to the dash cost.
The dash button or key is pressed.

Player can only jump if:
The jump button has been released since the last dash.
The player is on the floor.
The jump button or key is pressed.
The initial actions will help set the animation, ensure that attacking can only occur once, even in the same state, by setting a hasAttacked variable, and play the sword sound effect.
To avoid spamming any of the jumps, dashes, or attacks, require the player to release the key or button before they can be used again.
After being hit, allow for a moment of invulnerability, to avoid endlessly looping damage.
As this hero does not have a running attack, they can only transition from an attack into either idle or falling.

To transition back to idle, both the current animation AND the animation state is checked.
This is because the character could transition to this state with a finished animation from Running or Idle. By joining these two conditions the idle state only occurs when it should.

While there are a few different ways to implement a dash, this dash is intended to be viewed as a "Dodge/Evade" style dash.
As our character art doesn't have a custom dash animation, we have copied one frame from the running animation to make a new animation of "dash".
For this demo, we always want to ensure that the player cannot spam actions by holding down a button, so a toggle variable of "hasDashed" is set to 1. In other states, we need to ensure we're requiring this variable be 0 before we can dash.
To make it visible that we are dashing, we change the opacity to 100. This also gives us a shortcut when dealing with damage/knockback, as we can make Opacity of 255 a requirement before counting a "Hit".
At the start of this state we will reset the Dash timer, and unpause it as well.

Before dashing, ensure the following are true:
The hero is currently in the dash animation.
The timer has not reached the max dash time.
The timer is not pasued.

Begin the dash, depending on whether the player is flipped or not.
The length is used more as a speed here, since the timer is what decides when it stops.

Subtract the cost of the dash from the hero's current stamina. 
The dash cost is a global variable so it can be easily changed later for game tuning.
This should only trigger once during a dash.

To ensure the dash has completed, ensure the following are true:
The timer has reached our desired max dash time
The animation is still "Dash".
We then change our player opacity back to normal, and pause the timer.
Transition to idle state only if the animation is finished, the player is normal opacity, and the player is on the floor.
Transition to fall state if the player is not on solid ground when the dash completes.

These events are used to ensure that the player cannot hold a jump, dash, or attack button, and have the action spam whenever the hero switches states.
The variables listed must be 0 in order for the player to use the action again, so by not setting them back until the button is released we avoid spamming.
Do avoid jump spamming, we do n
Movement actions are in this state so the hero can change direction while jumping, without switching to the run animation.

Transition to the hit state if:
The player is not currently invulnerable (Opacity < 255).
The player collides with a member of the DamageToHero group.

Change the animation upon entering the hit state.
Change the opacity to indicate that the hero is currently invulnerable.
Start the hit recovery timer.
Store the default jump speed.
Play the hurt sound effect. (made using the built-in JFXR tool)

Subtract the damage of the enemy from the current hitpoints of the hero.
A clamp statement is used to ensure that the hero's HP never reduces below 0.
Knockback in appropriate direction depending on which direction the player is facing.

Air knockback logic:
The hit location is not on the ground.
The player is not on the floor.
The knockback timer is under the desired amount of time.

Complete the following once.
Change the jump speed for the desired amount of knockback.
Allow the player to jump again.
Simulate pressing the jump button.
Hold the opposite direction for knockback.

Ground knockback logic:
The hit location is not in the air.
The Player is on the floor.
The knockback timer is under the desired amount of time.
Change the jump speed back to normal if it was an air knockback.

Only start transitions to other states if:
The hit animation is complete.
If the knockback was in the air AND the air timer is past the desired time.
If the knockback was on the ground AND the ground timer is past the desired time.
When in a cutscene, change to a fall or idle animation depending on player's location.

The cutscene state does not require a transition as it is treated as a "Disable" state.
To ensure that the player is in the correct state once the cutscene is end, the state variable still gets updated.

If the player has more than 0 lives:
Fade out the game music and then play the death music. This is to ensure there's not a sudden restart of the scene upon death..
If the player fell into a pit, delete the HeroHitbox to stop the camera, then hide the hero sprite.
If the player did not fall into a pit, move the hero sprite to the DeathEffect layer, this is to give a visual indication of death.

Once the player has died, start fading the color scale of the hero sprite to black and white.
Adding TimeDelta() to the variable allows for different framerates to behave relatively the same, allowing for a smooth transition.
If the player has 0 lives, this needs to be treated as a game over.

A game over should be treated differently than normal player death.
Play the gameover music then set the opacity of both the FadeObject sprite and GameOver text to 0, so they are not visible when they are unhidden.
Start fading in the FadeObject sprite and GameOver text using a tween.
Wait until the music is done playing before subtracting the life and restarting the scene.
Wait until the music is done playing before resetting the checkpoint and going to the title screen.

Stamina should be regenerate only:
If not currently dashing or dead.
If at less than the max stamina.

Stamina is regenerated by taking the current stamina and adding the stamina regen rate. This is wrapped in a clamp expression to avoid going under the minimum (0) or over the maximum (the Hero object variable heroMaxStam)
At the beginning of the scene, hide the Camera Room objects.

As long as the player is in collision with the CameraRoom object and not the BossRoom, center the camera on the player WITHIN the CameraRoom object's boundaries.
This selects the current CameraRoom the player is in, and ensures the cameras stay within that range. In the future if the game was to be expanded with different rooms, this would mean it would flip the camera to the new CameraRoom boundaries once you enter it.
We duplicate this event for the Dash and Death effect layers, since they should both always mirror the main layer.
The parralax layer cameras should not move unless the main camera is moving, so their position is related specifically to the position of the base layer's camera position.

When not in collision with the BossRoom, the main, dash effect, and death effect layer cameras should follow the HeroHitbox object.
The CutsceneCamera object should stay centered on the HeroHitbox so its starting point feels "normal" when the game switches to following it.
Once in collision with the BossRoom, update the BossStart variable. This is used to trigger the Boss Start Cutscene.

The health bar is created as a 9-patch/panel sprite object. This is so we can modify the width without modifying the appearance of the sprite.
At the beginning of the scene, get the default width of the Health Bar. This is stored as a variable so we can use this for calculations later.

As the hero takes damage, we want to reduce the size of the health bar proportionally to the total percentage of HP vs Max HP. 
To make it look more "Pixel perfect" and less smooth, we want it to only move in increments of what one pixel would be. 
As the assets have been resized for 720p, one pixel is now 4 pixels. To get it to round to the nearest multiple of 4, we divide the updated width by 4, round the result down, then multiply by 4.
The stamina bar is handled identical to the health bar, but focuses on the current stamina vs max stamina of the hero.

The Lives are displayed via a text object that, GUILivesLabel.
This text object is updated to the current amount of lives stored as a global variable.

These events position the hero sprite over the hitbox object.
The hitbox object is used to guarantee that the movement and positioning of the hero is consistent, regardless of the hero animation.
If the hero object was used for movement directly, if the animations had different sizes, the sprite would jump around on the floor when animations change.

These events ensure the attack hotbox is positioned where it should be.
Actual attack collision and damage is dealt with in the enemy management events.

These events set any items added to the debug group as hidden at the start of the scene, then changes their opacity.
This is useful for when there are game objects used for logic but shouldn't be displayed during normal gameplay.

The following events show, hide, and position the debug items, but ONLY if being runned in a preview. 
This prevents these keys from working in the exported or final game.
Patroller movement should pause when "hit stunned". This is controled by the Enemy Combat Management events.

The patroller enemy has the platformer character behavior attached to it, with default controls disabled. This simplifies movement events.
The enemy should move based off the current direction in the object variable "Direction".
When in collision with a direction object, update the "Direction" variable.

A delayed chase enemy is an enemy that spawns in, then chases the player after a determined delay.
While you can apply the same logic to a group of enemies, since this has some custom animations for the Ghost it is being specifically identified in these events.

The ghost should be hidden by default so it can appear once the player is in range.
By using the Pause Timer action, the timer both created AND paused on the ghost.
Only process the AI Logic if the Ghost is visible.

When the player is in range of the ghost, start it's "Appear" animation, and unhide it.
The distance is set to 700, or slightly more than half the screen. This is to account for any difference on the Y position.
Ensure the attack variable is 0, then unpause the attack timer
Process the rest of the events only if the ghost is not hidden.
If the ghost is not idling, and the animation is finished, set the ghost to the idle animation.

If the ghost is not currently attacking, the player is in range of the ghost, AND the ghost is currently idling:
Reset the attack timer, then set the ghost to its Attack state by setting the Attack variable to 1.
Only complete the following actions if the ghost is in the attack state.
After a short period of time, record the angle between the ghost's location and the player's location.
Start the attack animation.

As part of the attack, compare the ghost's position to the player's and flip the sprite if necessary.
i.e. If the ghost's X position is greater than the player's, they are to the right of the player, and should be facing left (unflipped). If the ghost's X position is less than the player's, they are to the left of the player, and should be facing right (flipped).

After a short delay from recording the angle, push the ghost towards that angle.
The delay is added so the player can potentially avoid the ghost's attack, rather than it constantly following the player.
Wait longer before resetting the Attack state.

When the hero is in the attack animation and has their sword fully extended, check for collision with the attack hitbox.
If in collision, apply damage and activate the HitStun variable and timer.
Also set the enemy tint to red.
If currently hit stunned, and the timer is greater than 0.1, change the tint back and disable hitstun.

When a member of the Enemies group has 0 or less HP, create a death fire object below the enemy, then delete the enemy.
The deathfire should be centered on the center of the Enemy. This cannot be done through expressions as EnemyDeathFire.Width() will return 0 until after a single death fire exists in the scene. As the death fire is 176 wide, the event action is set up to move it back 88 pixels from the center of the enemy, which will center the fire on X.
For Y, this should be centered on the enemy just like X. Since the fire is 208 pixels tall, we move it up 104 pixels to center the fire on Y.

For normal enemies, a shorter death sound is played than the boss.
This is checked by comparing the current object name against the BossSkull object name.

The Dasher enemy should only start moving if the player is on the ground, and roughly on the same platform as the dasher.
This is being checked by comparing the Y position of the player against the Y position of the dasher.
The Dasher enemy should only move if they are on screen or about to be on screen. This is checked based off the Dasher's X position vs the center of the camera, and that the value is less than 1/2 the screen width (640).
This also only moves if the dasher is facing the direction of the player, by checking if the player's X position is less than the dasher enemy's if it is facing left (unflipped), or if the player's X position is greater than the dasher's if it is facing right (flipped).
This should only occur if the dasher hasn't already started to dash.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Bouh
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Add support for gamepads (or other controllers) to your game, giving access to information such as button presses, axis positions, axis force, trigger pressure, deadzone for each gamepad, etc...

Up to 4 gamepads can be connected: for each condition or expression, you'll have to enter the index of the gamepad to read. This is 1, 2,3 or 4.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Gamepads
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Add support for gamepads (or other controllers) to your game, giving access to information such as button presses, axis positions, trigger pressure, etc...

eventsFunctions.description: Get the value of the pressure on a gamepad trigger.
eventsFunctions.name: TriggerPressure

eventsFunctions.description:
Get the force value of a gamepad stick.
0 is stick on default position, 1 is at the maximum.
eventsFunctions.name: StickForce

eventsFunctions.description:
Get the rotation value of a gamepad stick.
If the deadzone value is high, the angle value is rounded to main axes, left, left, up, down.
An zero deadzone value give a total freedom on the angle value.
eventsFunctions.name: StickRotationValue

eventsFunctions.description: Get the value of axis of a gamepad stick.
eventsFunctions.name: AxisValue

eventsFunctions.description:
Test if a button is released on a gamepad. Buttons can be:
* Xbox: "A", "B", "X", "Y", "LB", "RB", "LT", "RT", "BACK", "START",
* PS4: "CROSS", "SQUARE", "CIRCLE", "TRIANGLE", "L1", "L2", "R1", "R2", "SHARE", "OPTIONS", "PS_BUTTON", "CLICK_TOUCHPAD",
* Other: "UP", "DOWN", "LEFT", "RIGHT", "CLICK_STICK_LEFT", "CLICK_STICK_RIGHT"
eventsFunctions.name: C_Button_released

eventsFunctions.description: Return the index of the last pressed button of a gamepad
eventsFunctions.name: LastButtonID

eventsFunctions.description: Check if any button is pressed on a gamepad.
eventsFunctions.name: C_Any_Button_pressed
eventsFunctions.sentence: Any button of gamepad _PARAM1_ is pressed

eventsFunctions.description:
Return the last button pressed. 
Buttons for Xbox and PS4 can be:
* Xbox: "A", "B", "X", "Y", "LB", "RB", "LT", "RT", "BACK", "START",
* PS4: "CROSS", "SQUARE", "CIRCLE", "TRIANGLE", "L1", "L2", "R1", "R2", "SHARE", "OPTIONS", "PS_BUTTON", "CLICK_TOUCHPAD",
* Both: "UP", "DOWN", "LEFT", "RIGHT", "CLICK_STICK_LEFT", "CLICK_STICK_RIGHT"
eventsFunctions.name: LastButtonString

parameters.description: Controller type "XBOX" or "PS4". This defines the type of button names to return as a string. "Mapping not exist" is returned if invalid type is used.
parameters.name: controller_type

eventsFunctions.description:
Check if a button is pressed on a gamepad. 
Buttons can be:
* Xbox: "A", "B", "X", "Y", "LB", "RB", "LT", "RT", "BACK", "START",
* PS4: "CROSS", "SQUARE", "CIRCLE", "TRIANGLE", "L1", "L2", "R1", "R2", "SHARE", "OPTIONS", "PS_BUTTON", "CLICK_TOUCHPAD",
* Other: "UP", "DOWN", "LEFT", "RIGHT", "CLICK_STICK_LEFT", "CLICK_STICK_RIGHT"
eventsFunctions.name: C_Button_pressed

eventsFunctions.description: Return the value of the deadzone applied to a gamepad sticks, between 0 and 1.
eventsFunctions.name: Deadzone

eventsFunctions.description: Set the deadzone for sticks of the gamepad. The deadzone is an area for which movement on sticks won't be taken into account (instead, the stick will be considered as not moved). Deadzone is between 0 and 1, and is by default 0.2.
eventsFunctions.name: A_Set_deadzone
eventsFunctions.sentence: Set deadzone for sticks on gamepad: _PARAM1_ to _PARAM2_

parameters.description: Deadzone for sticks, 0.2 by default (0 to 1)
parameters.name: deadzone

eventsFunctions.description: Check if a stick of a gamepad is pushed in a given direction.
eventsFunctions.name: C_Axis_pushed
eventsFunctions.sentence: _PARAM2_ stick of gamepad _PARAM1_ is pushed in direction _PARAM3_

eventsFunctions.description: Return the number of connected gamepads
eventsFunctions.name: ConnectedGamepadsCount

eventsFunctions.description: Return a string containing informations about the specified gamepad
eventsFunctions.name: GamepadType

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the specified gamepad has the specified information in its description. Useful to know if the gamepad is a Xbox or PS4 controller.
eventsFunctions.name: C_Controller_type

eventsFunctions.description: Check if a gamepad is connected.
eventsFunctions.name: C_Controller_X_is_connected

eventsFunctions.description: Generate a vibration on the specified controller. Might only work if the game is running in a recent web browser.
eventsFunctions.name: A_Vibrate_controller

parameters.description: Time of the vibration, in seconds (optional, default value is 1)
parameters.name: duration

eventsFunctions.description: Check if any button is released on a gamepad.
eventsFunctions.name: C_any_button_released
eventsFunctions.sentence: Any button of gamepad _PARAM1_ is released
